description:
Pisolithus orientalis is a species of puffball fungus belonging to the genus Pisolithus. It is found in various regions of Asia, including China, Japan, and Korea.

Pisolithus orientalis is a hypogeous fungus, meaning it grows underground and produces its fruiting bodies beneath the soil surface. The mature fruiting body is roughly spherical in shape, typically ranging from 3 to 10 centimeters in diameter.

The outer surface of the fruiting body is brownish-gray in color and has a rough, scaly texture. When the fruiting body matures, it develops a network of compartments or "cells" within, which contain the spores. These spores are released through small openings on the surface of the fruiting body, contributing to the dispersal of the species.

Pisolithus orientalis is known to form ectomycorrhizal associations with the roots of various tree species, including pines and oaks, playing a beneficial role in the growth and health of these plants. The fungus helps the host plants to absorb water and nutrients from the soil more efficiently.

This species is considered an important edible fungus in some Asian countries, where it is collected and consumed as a food source. However, caution is advised as some individuals may have allergic reactions to the consumption of Pisolithus orientalis.
